headline: President takes Trump doctrine on the road
subHeadline: This is a rush transcript from "The Fox News Specialists," May 19, 2017.

utterances.speaker: KATHERINE TIMPF, THE FOX NEWS SPECIALIST HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Kat Timpf along with Eric Bolling and Eboni K Williams. We are The Fox News Specialists.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: President Trump is currently en route to Saudi Arabia with the first lady Melania Trump, leaving the United States just hours ago to kick off his first overseas trip. The president is slated to meet with the Saudi king and other members of the Saudi royal family during his stop with combating terrorism expected to be a major focus. The president is also scheduled visit Israel including a meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. Then onto the Vatican which will include an audience with Pope Francis. In a stop in Belgium where President Trump is expected to reaffirm the U.S. commitment to NATO. And finally, President Trump will wrap up the 8-day trip attending the G-7 summit on the island of Sicily.  And with the president in the air, anonymous leakers are behind two fresh reports taking direct aim at President Trump. The New York Times is reporting that during his meeting with Russian officials last week, President Trump called former FBI director James Comey a, quote, real nut job. And that Comey's firing had relieved, quote, great pressure on him. Meanwhile, the Washington Post is reporting that a senior White House official is now a significant person of interest in the Russia probe. Don't forget, however, that both newspapers have had to walk back other recent reports about Comey and Russia, so it's really hard to know who to trust at this point. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb2', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb2', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

And I know where you guys are coming from, but, you know, this is America where peaceful protests is protected by the First Amendment. They completely overstepped their bounds. I don't know that you dispel the ambassador, as McCain said and you pointed out, Bernie. But I think you do, you know, lean on him a little bit. Maybe even talk to him about possibly, you know, pushing back on some of the things that we maybe wanted to be do with him. You can't do -- that was -- when I first saw that, I was positive that was not in America. And -- that was, like, a movie set. It's crazy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And I think that's the point, Eric. I agree with you fully. You guys have this strong message that we don't do this. We don't do it. We don't tolerate. We don't condone it. Even if, ultimately, we decide that there's some business we can do together around some other interests, that's not okay. Look at his reaction. It's super suspect, right? I mean, he is not even bothered whatsoever. I mean, I tend to think that, yes, he knew it was -- at least knew it was coming.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I think --

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: It's no better than the Mayor of Berkeley who stood by and watched, for eight hours, the chairs being thrown through windows and people getting their butts kicked.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I would argue that it's probably a little better than the Mayor of Berkeley.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm going to go with (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: I'm with you.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Just saying. I think that we never really do ourselves any favors when we try to get too involved and decide who will be in the leadership in these countries, as you pointed out. I completely agree with you there. But at the same time, someone doing something like that, which affects our people and the constitutionally protected right on our soil, there needs to be a little bit more anger about that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Continue, Eric.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Do you know what goes on over here during U.N. General Counsel?

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: That -- these diplomats come over here, they speed, they break all the rules, traffic violation, park wherever they want. They go into clubs. They actually hire prostitutes and we have to sit back and go, "Well, that's against all of our laws, but we can't touch them." I mean, they have diplomatic immunity. These guys -- I guarantee they have diplomatic immunity.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This video of watching these people beat up --

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: I guarantee that we can't touch these guys.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think we can't touch them, Eric, you're right. But I think that politicians would -- McCain, whoever coming out condemning it strongly is important.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: That's OK. That's OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think it's important. I think it's necessary. Because otherwise, we don't want to send the message that this is OK. When you come over here, we suspend all of our cultural norms and get down how you get down. Because we (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: It was nice seeing Ann Coulter and Milo in that video too. That was very nice.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: All right, all right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I missed it.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Did you miss that part?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: All right. Anthony Weiner, facing the music over his child sexting case. How long could the disgraced former congressman face in prison after a guilty plea today? We're coming right back.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This morning, former congressman, Anthony Weiner, AKA Carlos Danger, pleaded guilty to transferring obscene material to a minor. In the courtroom, Weiner read a statement saying, quote, "I accept full responsibility for my conduct. I have a sickness, but I do not have an excuse." As part of his plea agreement, he will have to register as a sex offender. He'll also surrender passport, forfeit his iPhone, and is barred from having any further contact with the girl. So I'm going to start with both Bernie and Sid on this. I know you both have young daughters. Yours is 13, yours, recent college graduate. I have to ask you, as a father, is there anything close to justice, looking familiar in this situation for you?

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: I'd say -- well, I heard he's looking at 23 months, a minimum.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Twenty-one to twenty-seven months in jail.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: And he said he would not appeal that. He would be OK with that, 21 to 27 months.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And that's what the prosecutor's read. But is that amount of time in jail justice for you as fathers of young girls? I mean, this girl was literally 15 years old.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: Actually, maybe not. Maybe he could do a little more time. I would be -- if it was me and my daughter and I caught him live, I mean, I might put a knife in his neck or something like that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's my question.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: But anyway, you know what I'm hoping? First of all, he and Bill Clinton were this close to the center of power. Can you imagine Anthony Weiner and Bill Clinton standing on stage while Hillary's getting sworn in as president? Anyway, it didn't happen. Thank the Lord Jesus. But here's what I'm hoping. He cut a deal with the federal prosecutors. He knows something about the Hillary corruption that he said, "Look, I have something for you guys," which is why he's going to get such a small sentence. That's what I'm -- that's my --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what you're thinking?

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: That's my thinking.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm going to push back on that. I'm going to get you and Sid -- I'm thinking no. I'm thinking if it were like that, he wouldn't be serving any jail time, if he had a fish that big.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Agreed.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: This is a pretty standard plea deal that's been made.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Right, and he'll do with 21 months and he'll say, "I'll never do it again." Look, I think -- and I really mean this. I think for guys or gals that do crimes like this, he should be castrated. I mean this sincerely, I'm not kidding.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: Chemically?

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Chemically castrated. So --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: So you thought about it?

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: Yes, we talked about it today.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Oh, we talk about something (INAUDIBLE) on NBC today. When you commit a sex crime and is a pedophile, you should be castrated. Because when he gets out of jail in two years, guess what? He's going to be hunting for the next 15-year-old.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: He said, "I have a sickness, but don't have an excuse." Which is like saying, "It's not my fault, but I accept responsibility." He's such a victim. He's a victim and he's messaged this girl, like, "My wife, she doesn't want me anymore, and now I have to take care of the baby," and I was like, "Oh, it's so sad. I was getting better and then I messed up." He still sees himself as a victim. He thinks the world owes him something. He's never going to change. It's going to be really hard for him to go --

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: And what a fall from grace. This guy could have been mayor. His wife could have been in the White House. You would look at Anthony Weiner as a big-time guy in this country, and now he's reduced to this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Eric, here's my question to you. To this notion of rehabilitation -- because he said he was in treatment and recovering. Is it possible? Do you think it's possible for these sex offenders to be rehabilitated?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: This guy?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: No. If you watched the documentary of Weiner, it's one of the most compelling documentaries you will see. And they followed Weiner through mayoral candidacy, and he gets twice during the documentary on camera of doing this stuff.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: It's amazing. It's amazing.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: But you honestly have to feel bad for I'm Huma Abedin. I mean, you see her, while this -- the camera rolling.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: And the kids -- and her kids.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: And they're, so to speak, exposing Anthony Weiner for what he's been doing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, Eric, you and your pun.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: I mean, it's -- no, no, no. I'm telling you, you have to feel bad for Huma Abedin in this because she is just caught blindsided by this -- by his obviously disgusting behavior.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I feel like you would say you were blindsided the first time, maybe you're blindsided the second time. You're not blindsided the third time.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Well, and that's like the battered wife. You know, she's been beaten for years. She's still the victim in this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think she's a victim.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: This is feeds into my theory that maybe he has something because she kept him close, so he wouldn't spill all the beans. Otherwise, what's the explanation of keeping him around all this time?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Because exposing him at the time would have ruined Hillary.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: He's so good-looking.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: How about James Comey's ineptness, intent? He had classified material on his laptop.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: I think that's probably incorrect.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: His disgusting, sleazy laptop that she put there. Intent. What do you mean intent? It was there. That's a crime right there. Where was Comey on that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that's the point too, is ultimately, this did lead to Hillary -- talk about Huma, I mean, she had a horrible year. Ultimately, this stuff led to the reinvestigation of Hillary during --and Hillary, to this day, says that's why she lost. Now, we know that's not true. But here's the other thing, Eric, we saw that Anthony, during his weeping -- he was crying. A grown man crying in open court around this plea deal, still wearing his wedding ring, right? But Huma not there. What in the world?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: He is sick. He is a sick human being for him to continue to do this time and time again, continuing to get caught, saying he's into the going to do it again. Gets caught again. He is an absolute -- pathological, maybe?

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. A habitual, pathological.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: But I think, I really believe -- you know, it was always about her and Tony Goldwyn in Hollywood. I really believe she wants to give it a try because of the child. I do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think she was obsessed because I heard rumors on how they got started -- or really documented that she thought he was very unattractive, to your point, Kat. Didn't like him. Shunned him.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: But he was funny and smart.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Funny and smart, and I think she saw --

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Yes. My (INAUDIBLE) the same thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, Sid. Yes, right. I think she saw a lot of potential. A lot of political potential in him. I mean, he was a very brilliant mind for the Democratic Party for a long time. And ultimately, it was his own undoing.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: Maybe after the first time. Not after the second time. To me, something stinks.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: And then the third time, and then now, it's a kid.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my god.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Come on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: In so many ways, Kat. Well, don't go back -- when we come back, we're going to circle back with our specialist folks, Sid and Bernie. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: All right. Time to circle back with our specialists, Bernie McGuirk and Sid Rosenberg. Guys, one question we've been getting on Twitter during the show. "How can people listen to your radio? Where can they hear you?"

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: WABCradio.com. There's an app. There's also iHeartRadio. And we're on 77 on the WABC Radio in New York City. In the tri-state area.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: I'm going to throw you a real quick question. How's my friend Don Imus doing?

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: He's killing it. Doing great. His health is good and he's just fiery and feisty as ever.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: He's (INAUDIBLE) but I think it likes it.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: And we're both on that show. Our day starts at 6:00 A.M. with Imus.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: We do 6:00 to 9:00 on Imus and we do our own show from 9:00 to noon. So we're on six hours a day on the (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Do you sleep at all?

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: No? Just know no?

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: Absolutely not. It's -- what is that, by the way?

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: The only -- I think he's stuck at 82. About the last?

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: Plentyof time for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK, Sid --

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Do you got a question?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. Your watch is, like, smacking me in the face right now along with your cuff link.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Can we give this guy a little glam cam.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: And you know what's funny about this? Take a look at this. This looks like it probably cost a couple thousand dollars, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: There it is.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: But here's the God honest truth -- are we're on T.V.?

utterances.speaker: WILLAIMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: You looked like you mugged 50 Cent.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Right. The watch is 200 bucks, and the cuff links?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes?

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Forty.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: These cuff links remind me of my pageant days. Stunning. They're absolutely stunning.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: $240. But it looks…

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But it looks like a million bucks.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Right, 240 bucks…

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: When he gets on the subway to go home, he takes it off and puts it in his pocket.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: I do.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Well, if you're going out wearing clothes that look expensive, if you're going to tell everybody they're not expensive.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: I shouldn't do that, right?

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You shouldn't do that. You just blew it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I like it, I like it. Relatable.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: I want to put a little --

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Anything…

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was going to -- I was -- I wondered when he slept, so I already asked that. He says he does not.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: So now --

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: You see him on Twitter, like, all hours of the night.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: TIMPF
utterances.sentences: Are you a human being? I just wondered.

utterances.speaker: MCGUIRK
utterances.sentences: My daughter just graduated from college. It was six hours up, six hours back this past weekend. No, sleep? I'm looking forward to it one of these days. But it'll come.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: My mother always says -- old Jewish lady, young Jewish lady -- you sleep when you're dead. So -- we're not going to sleep tonight. You know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: My mom says that's crazy.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: All right, you guys --

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: At this rate, it could be any day.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: We enjoyed having you, especially on a Friday. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ROSENBERG
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BOLLING
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much, and thank you for our "Fox News Specialists", these guys, Bernie McGuirk and Sid Rosenberg, and thank all of you for watching. Make sure to follow us on social media. Specialists, FNC on Twitter, Facebook. Remember, five o'clock. Bret Baier now.

utterances.speaker: JAMES ROSEN, FBN HOST
utterances.sentences: This is a Fox News Alert. I am James Rosen, sitting in for Brett Baier.
